results.abstract: Roundup of films due for release this summer; photos (L)

headline.main: A Plate Heaped With Romance; Hold the Gorillas

results.snippet: THERE'S something different about this year's crop of summer movies. Most of the action heroes are sitting the season out, so not a single comet, meteor, dinosaur or giant gorilla is poised to destroy us all. Instead there are a swarm of romantic...
results.lead_paragraph: THERE'S something different about this year's crop of summer movies. Most of the action heroes are sitting the season out, so not a single comet, meteor, dinosaur or giant gorilla is poised to destroy us all. Instead there are a swarm of romantic comedies, lovable animated robots and apemen for the children, and more restorations, rereleases and directors' cuts than you can shake a light-saber at. In this selective list, some opening dates are for New York only and at least a few are sure to change even as you're reading this. Sequels, Prequels and Remakes THE MUMMY A romantic adventure version of the 1932 Boris Karloff horror picture. It's still about a 3,000-year-old Egyptian corpse that comes to life, complete with terrible curse. Brendan Fraser stars as a dashing legionnaire; Rachel Weisz is his Egypt-savvy love interest. Directed by Stephen Sommers. Opens Friday.

results.abstract: Trent Lott Leadership Institute, academic center under construction at University of Mississippi, is being endowed with million-dollar donations from companies with huge stakes in pending Congressional legislation; university officials report collecting in less than six months more than half of $8 million needed for center, scheduled to open in 2000, and hope to raise still more at Kennedy Center gala honoring Senate majority leader; donors include MCI Worldcom Inc and Lockheed Martin Corp, each of which has pledged $1 million; while type of fund-raising for academic centers is not new, Lott Institute has drawn unusually heavy corporate support, all tax-deductable; photo (M)

headline.main: Donors Flock to University Center Linked to Senate Majority Leader

results.snippet: An academic center under construction at the University of Mississippi and named for Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, is being endowed with million-dollar donations from companies with huge stakes in pending Congressional legislation.    In...
results.lead_paragraph: An academic center under construction at the University of Mississippi and named for Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, is being endowed with million-dollar donations from companies with huge stakes in pending Congressional legislation. In less than six months, university officials say, they have collected pledges for more than half of the $8 million they hope to raise for the center, the Trent Lott Leadership Institute, which is scheduled to open next year. Among the donors are MCI Worldcom Inc. and the Lockheed Martin Corporation, each of which has pledged $1 million. The companies are on opposite sides of a legislative battle over Lockheed's planned acquisition of a giant satellite company.

results.abstract: Iver Peterson Our Towns column on new security rules adopted at South Brunswick (NJ) High School that have added to unease at school; new rules were implemented after school killings in Littleton, Colo; South Brunswick's principal Thomas Kietrys comments (M)

headline.main: Our Towns; For Students, Security Rules Add to Unease

results.snippet: LAST fall, town officials wanted to put a full-time plainclothes police officer in South Brunswick High School. The hope was that students would get to know the police a little better and everyone would be a little safer. But some seniors objected on...
results.lead_paragraph: LAST fall, town officials wanted to put a full-time plainclothes police officer in South Brunswick High School. The hope was that students would get to know the police a little better and everyone would be a little safer. But some seniors objected on principle and the idea was shelved. Now there are two full-time officers in South Brunswick High, in uniform, and their squad cars are parked conspicuously in front. In this season of concern about school violence, nobody asked the students about them, or about keeping more school access doors locked or the new ban on wearing long coats or carrying backpacks in school between classes.

results.abstract: Duke University Medical Center becomes third major research institution in six months that is forced to halt Federally financed human experiments for failing to adhere to ethical guidelines; also halts voluntarily enrollment in privately financed research; each of its 2,000 experiments will be reviewed by center and Federal investigators to determine whether patients should be removed; Federal investigators, citing wide variety of lapses, say all experiments should be halted unless patients are receiving significant therapeutic benefits; describe summer 1998 experiment in which volunteer was injured; raise questions over whether subjects are adequately informed of risks; violations come at time of huge increase in number of experiments on humans that need to be monitored; Duke officials characterize problems as mostly administrative (M)

headline.main: Ethics Lapses at Duke Halt Dozens of Human Experiments

results.snippet: Dozens of human experiments at Duke University Medical Center came to a halt today, surprising many staff members as they arrived on a warm and flowering spring morning at the huge medical complex here.    On Tuesday, Duke became the third major...

byline.original: By PHILIP J. HILTS with SHERYL GAY STOLBERG

results.lead_paragraph: Dozens of human experiments at Duke University Medical Center came to a halt today, surprising many staff members as they arrived on a warm and flowering spring morning at the huge medical complex here. On Tuesday, Duke became the third major research institution in six months to be forced to halt federally financed research because of accusations that it failed to meet Federal ethical rules. Most of the center's 2,000 experiments involving humans is federally financed.

results.abstract: James Sterngold article profiles Don Cheadle, who stars in HBO movie A Lesson Before Dying; film, directed by Rob Cohen, focuses on race relations in the South during 1940's; photo (M)

headline.main: Playing It Again: Lone Black Man In a Racist World

results.snippet: AFTER making a name for himself largely by playing slick gangsters, Don Cheadle was given the kind of breakout offer that actors pray for: the part of Sammy Davis Jr. in the HBO movie ''The Rat Pack.''     He turned it down.
results.lead_paragraph: AFTER making a name for himself largely by playing slick gangsters, Don Cheadle was given the kind of breakout offer that actors pray for: the part of Sammy Davis Jr. in the HBO movie ''The Rat Pack.'' He turned it down.

results.abstract: word for word/civil war lit: mine eyes have seen the coming of a lot o

headline.main: Word for Word/Civil War Lit; Mine Eyes Have Seen the Coming Of a Lot of Wacky Stuff

results.snippet: GERTRUDE STEIN put it best: ''There never will be anything more interesting in America than that Civil War never.''     Interest in the war rarely wanes, but it definitely waxes around this time of year. After Memorial Day (which evolved from...
results.lead_paragraph: GERTRUDE STEIN put it best: ''There never will be anything more interesting in America than that Civil War never.'' Interest in the war rarely wanes, but it definitely waxes around this time of year. After Memorial Day (which evolved from mourning rituals for the Civil War's 620,000 dead), hardly a week will pass this summer without a battle anniversary, a combat re-enactment or a rite of remembrance.

results.abstract: Apollo astronauts and their predecessors on Gemini program took many photographs of their adventures, often producing pictures with a lonely splendor and startling artistry; some of them appear in the forthcoming book Full Moon; photos (L)

headline.main: How the Moon Turns Pilots Into Poets

results.snippet: The men chosen to fly to the Moon, among them two who walked on its surface for the first time 30 years ago, were not picked for their poetic minds or for their photographic skills.    The astronauts in the Apollo space program of the late 1960's and...
results.lead_paragraph: The men chosen to fly to the Moon, among them two who walked on its surface for the first time 30 years ago, were not picked for their poetic minds or for their photographic skills. The astronauts in the Apollo space program of the late 1960's and early 70's were mostly superb test pilots who courted death every time they rode on top of a six-million-pound rocket to get into Earth's orbit before they could be on their way to the Moon some 240,000 miles away.

results.abstract: Beverly Lewis, vice president and senior editor at Bantam Books, dies at age 51 (S)

headline.main: Beverly Lewis, 51, Editor at Bantam Books

results.snippet: Beverly Lewis, a vice president and senior editor at Bantam Books,  died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 51 and lived in Manhattan.    Ms. Lewis died on the way to a hospital after collapsing on a Manhattan street, her husband, Sandy Eames, said. The...
results.lead_paragraph: Beverly Lewis, a vice president and senior editor at Bantam Books, died on Monday in Manhattan. She was 51 and lived in Manhattan. Ms. Lewis died on the way to a hospital after collapsing on a Manhattan street, her husband, Sandy Eames, said. The family is awaiting results of an autopsy.

results.abstract: John Russell reviews exhibit of tiny paintings by several famous twentieth-century artists, at Yoshii Gallery; photo (S)

headline.main: A Pocket Tour of the Century in 86 Small Works

results.snippet: Byron once said of something that it was ''Little, but to the purpose.'' This can be true of things either written or said, and it can also be true of works of art. It can certainly be applied to the 86 paintings, sculptures, drawings and photographs...
results.lead_paragraph: Byron once said of something that it was ''Little, but to the purpose.'' This can be true of things either written or said, and it can also be true of works of art. It can certainly be applied to the 86 paintings, sculptures, drawings and photographs in the current exhibition at the Yoshii Gallery. Together they amount to a pocket history of 20th-century art. Almost all the big names are there, from Matisse and Picasso to Miro and Arp and Magritte and Calder and Dubuffet and Pollock. Among today's front-runners are Ellsworth Kelly, Brice Marden, Gerhard Richter, John Chamberlain, Kiki Smith and Sol LeWitt.

results.snippet: A Musical Farewell    THURSDAY -- The Brooklyn Academy of Music will pay tribute to Harvey Lichtenstein, who is leaving his post as the academy's president and executive producer. The event, at the academy's opera house, 30 Lafayette Avenue (Ashland...
results.lead_paragraph: A Musical Farewell THURSDAY -- The Brooklyn Academy of Music will pay tribute to Harvey Lichtenstein, who is leaving his post as the academy's president and executive producer. The event, at the academy's opera house, 30 Lafayette Avenue (Ashland Place), will include performances by the singers Paul Simon and Lou Reed, the dancers and choreographers Trisha Brown and Chuck Davis, and the composer Philip Glass. Proceeds will benefit the academy's artistic, community and educational programs. After the performance, dinner will follow under tents nearby. Tickets, $600, or $50 to $100 for the cocktail reception and performance alone, from (718) 636-4174. Chinese Legacy

results.abstract: Discovery astronauts Tamara Jernigan and Dr Daniel Barry go on space walk to spruce up outside of new international space station (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Crew Begins Space Walk and Work on Outside of Station

results.snippet: With their docking behind them, Discovery's astronauts went on a space walk tonight to spruce up the outside of the new international space station.    The astronauts, Tamara Jernigan and Dr. Daniel Barry, floated out of the space shuttle about 11...
results.lead_paragraph: With their docking behind them, Discovery's astronauts went on a space walk tonight to spruce up the outside of the new international space station. The astronauts, Tamara Jernigan and Dr. Daniel Barry, floated out of the space shuttle about 11 P.M. The seven-story station loomed above them, jutting out of Discovery's cargo bay.

results.abstract: What's Doing In column offers suggestions on events, sightseeing, hotels and restaurants in Portland, Ore; map; table of vital statistics; photo (M)
results.snippet: Of the three West Coast sisters, the Portland historian Terence O'Donnell once said, San Francisco grew up as the debutante, Seattle the tart and Portland the spinster. That characterization never bothered most people in Oregon's biggest city very...
results.lead_paragraph: Of the three West Coast sisters, the Portland historian Terence O'Donnell once said, San Francisco grew up as the debutante, Seattle the tart and Portland the spinster. That characterization never bothered most people in Oregon's biggest city very much -- they were content with their demure hometown, and just as happy that the rest of the country didn't pay it undue attention. But in recent years, Portland has become more like Cinderella. This verdant, biker- and pedestrian-friendly city, which tore down a freeway to make room for a magnificent riverfront park, is routinely held up as a national model of how to do things right. On long summer days, with snowy Mount Hood looming to the east, it is one of the most beautiful urban settings anywhere.
